elements.content: We report a two-dimensional Hofmann-like spin-crossover (SCO) material, [Fe­(trz-py)2{Pt­(CN)4}]·3H2O, built from [FePt­(CN)4] layers separated by interdigitated 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (trz-py) ligands with two symmetrically inequivalent FeII sites. This compound exhibits an incomplete first-order spin transition at 153 K between fully high-spin (HS–HS) and intermediate high-spin low-spin (HS–LS) ordered states. At low temperature, it undergoes a bidirectional photoswitching to HS–HS and fully low-spin (LS–LS) states with green and near-IR light irradiation, respectively, with associated T­(LIESST = Light-Induced Excited Spin-State Trapping) and T­(reverse-LIESST) values of 52 and 85 K, respectively. Photomagnetic investigations show that the reverse-LIESST process, performed from either HS-HS or HS-LS states, enables access to a hidden stable LS-LS state, revealing the existence of a hidden thermal hysteresis. Crystallographic investigations allowed to identify that the strong metastability of the HS-LS state originates from the existence of a strong elastic frustration causing antiferroelastic interactions within the [FePt­(CN)4] layers, through the rigid NC-Pt-CN bridges connecting the inequivalent FeII sites. The existence of the stable LS-LS state paves the way for a multidirectional photoswitching and allows potential applications for electronic devices based on ternary digits.

Photomagnetic investigations show that the reverse-LIESST process, performed from either HS-HS or HS-LS states, enables access to a hidden stable LS-LS state, revealing the existence of a hidden thermal hysteresis. elements.content: We report a two-dimensional Hofmann-like spin-crossover (SCO) material experiencing strong elastic frustration leading to an incomplete spin transition. Under light, a hidden stable low spin state is reached, revealing the existence of a hidden thermal hysteresis and multistability features. The existence of these characteristics paves the way for a multidirectional photoswitching and allows potential applications for electronic devices based on ternary digits.

Under light, a hidden stable low spin state is reached, revealing the existence of a hidden thermal hysteresis and multistability features. The existence of these characteristics paves the way for a multidirectional photoswitching and allows potential applications for electronic devices based on ternary digits.

elements.content: Spin-crossover (SCO) materials, in particular those exhibiting thermal and photoinduced magnetic bistability, are likely among the most studied switchable molecular solids in the past few years. In general, this property occurs for the first-row transition-metal complexes of d4–d7 electronic configurations when the spin pairing energy is close to the ligand-field strength, producing changes in their magnetic, optical, and structural properties. So far, the most studied examples are those based on FeII (d6 configuration), for which a paramagnetic–diamagnetic transition from the high-spin (HS) state (S = 2, 5T2g) to the low-spin (LS) state (S = 0, 1A1g) is observed with temperature. Photoconversion of the LS stable state into the HS metastable state has been evidenced at low temperature and shown to be reversible in some complexes. This allows a bidirectional photoswitching between a reference state (0) and an excited state (1) with a long lifetime, as long as the experiment is performed at low temperature. Going further, it is of huge interest to be able to reach different states from the same reference state, with a high contrast in at least one physical property. Such multiaddressable systems with at least three states (0, 1+, 1−) are quite rare. Except the particular case of the [Fe­(ptz)6]­(BF4)2 (ptz = 1-propyltetrazole) compound for which the multistability comes from the single-molecule magnet behavior of the photoinduced metastable state, the observation of multi­(meta)­stability arises from the presence of multiple switchable sites. In the example of the binuclear system {[Fe­(bt)­(NCS)2]2(bpm)}, irradiation in the visible range induces population of the fully paramagnetic HS–HS state, while irradiation in the near-IR populates the intermediate HS–LS phase. Regarding the mononuclear compound, the presence of at least two inequivalent FeII sites can lead to a stepped SCO or an incomplete transition with one FeII that remains in the HS state. Using the reverse-LIESST process, this thermally trapped HS state can be switched to LS. From this new state, a new SCO temperature can be recorded that corresponds to the SCO of the second FeII site. One interesting but rarely observed property is that this trapped site may undergo a first-order phase transition, giving rise to a hidden thermal hysteresis and so to a hidden bistability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Spin-crossover (SCO) materials, in particular those exhibiting thermal and photoinduced magnetic bistability, are likely among the most studied switchable molecular solids in the past few years. In general, this property occurs for the first-row transition-metal complexes of d4-d7 electronic configurations when the spin pairing energy is close to the ligand-field strength, producing changes in their magnetic, optical, and structural properties. So far, the most studied examples are those based on FeII (d6 configuration), for which a paramagnetic-diamagnetic transition from the high-spin (HS) state (S = 2, 5T2g) to the low-spin (LS) state (S = 0, 1A1g) is observed with temperature. Photoconversion of the LS stable state into the HS metastable state has been evidenced at low temperature and shown to be reversible in some complexes. This allows a bidirectional photoswitching between a reference state (0) and an excited state (1) with a long lifetime, as long as the experiment is performed at low temperature. Going further, it is of huge interest to be able to reach different states from the same reference state, with a high contrast in at least one physical property. Such multiaddressable systems with at least three states (0, 1+, 1-) are quite rare. Except the particular case of the [Fe(ptz)6](BF4)2 (ptz = 1-propyltetrazole) compound for which the multistability comes from the single-molecule magnet behavior of the photoinduced metastable state, the observation of multi(meta)stability arises from the presence of multiple switchable sites. In the example of the binuclear system {[Fe(bt)(NCS)2]2(bpm)}, irradiation in the visible range induces population of the fully paramagnetic HS-HS state, while irradiation in the near-IR populates the intermediate HS-LS phase. Regarding the mononuclear compound, the presence of at least two inequivalent FeII sites can lead to a stepped SCO or an incomplete transition with one FeII that remains in the HS state. Using the reverse-LIESST process, this thermally trapped HS state can be switched to LS. From this new state, a new SCO temperature can be recorded that corresponds to the SCO of the second FeII site. One interesting but rarely observed property is that this trapped site may undergo a first-order phase transition, giving rise to a hidden thermal hysteresis and so to a hidden bistability.

elements.content: In this context, Brest’s group and others have directed their efforts toward the so-called polymeric strategy to better control the supramolecular organization in the crystal packing and possibly to enhance cooperative effects and magnetic interactions. Such studies provided several original systems such as SCO neutral chains, based on flexible cyanocarbanion or rigid inorganic tetracyanometallate ([M­(CN)4]2–, where M = NiII, PtII, PdII) ligands, which can act as polybridging ligands through their nitrile groups. In the same timeframe, three-dimensional (3D) Hofmann-like metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) based on tetracynometallate anions have been extensively studied. However, the system based on cyanocarbanion flexible ligands exhibited weak cooperativity, while the 3D Hofmann-like systems displayed strong molecular cooperativity without significant photoinduced effects, even if it has been shown that these bimetallic materials can be organized on surfaces or dots for applications in molecular electronics. The objective of this work is to design new systems exhibiting multi­(meta)­stability. So, we extended the previous polymeric strategy to reach processable Hofmann-like MOFs, which will help in the observation and control of the three state (0, 1+, 1−) configurations. On the basis of our achievements gained through our previous studies of SCO chains involving a cyanocarbanion, cyanometallate anions, and 3D Hofmann-like systems, we have extended our investigations to bimetallic systems based on [FeIIMII(CN)4] two-dimensional (2D) layers and other monodentate aromatic N-donor coligands. It is expected that the tuning of the flexibility/rigidity of the coligands, which play a crucial role in the propagation of the acoustic waves, may strongly impact the interaction between SCO units. This would allow control of the interlayer interactions, resulting in significant changes in the properties of the thermal (transition temperature and/or thermal hysteresis loop) and photoinduced (photoinduced effects, LIESST temperature, and subsequent relaxation curves) transition regimes of the SCO material. To this end and because the 2D SCO based on Hofmann-like frameworks are, up to now, essentially limited to pyridyl N-donor ligands, we focus here our investigations on other aromatic N-donor ligands such as functionalized azole ligands involving two or more N-donor atoms.

elements.content: So, we report herein the synthesis, thermal variation of the crystallographic structural data, and magnetic properties of the 2D SCO Hofmann-like system [Fe­(trz-py)2{Pt­(CN)4}]·3H2O [1; trz-py = 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole], based on the N-donor-functionalized triazole ligand (see for a comprehensive view of the 2D structural architecture). The photoswitching processes involved in this multi­(meta)­stable and bidirectional photoswitching Hofmann-type MOF are discussed in light of full photomagnetic and photocrystallographic investigations. The magnetic properties of 1 reveal an incomplete spin transition, leading to an ordered HS–LS configuration at low temperature. This state can be switched by light irradiation, using an adequate wavelength, to either HS–HS or LS–LS configurations whose thermal stabilities have been analyzed. An original result brought by the present work lies with the clear identification of the elastic frustration within the Fe–Pt–Fe–Pt pseudosquares as the physical origin of the incomplete spin transition, in excellent agreement with very recent theoretical predictions. It should be pointed out that, recently, the coordination polymer [Fe­(thtrz)2Pd­(CN)4]·(EtOH)­(H2O) (thtrz = N-thiophenylidene-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine) was communicated as the first 2D SCO Hofmann-like coordination polymer based on triazole ligands, which revealed a complete two-step conversion.

The magnetic properties of 1 reveal an incomplete spin transition, leading to an ordered HS-LS configuration at low temperature. This state can be switched by light irradiation, using an adequate wavelength, to either HS-HS or LS-LS configurations whose thermal stabilities have been analyzed. elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared as a polycrystalline powder by adding K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O to an aqueous solution containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole and iron­(II) perchlorate in a 1:2:1 ratio. The corresponding single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained using a diffusion technique in fine glass tube (3.0 mm diameter) by careful layering of an aqueous solution containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole and iron­(II) perchlorate onto an aqueous solution of K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O. Room-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of the polycrystalline powder was performed to confirm the isomorphism of the powders by comparison with the simulated PXRD pattern for the corresponding single-crystal sample. As is clearly indicated by Figure S1, the measured pattern of a microcrystalline powder of 1 is indeed qualitatively similar to the pattern calculated from the single-crystal crystallographic data. The absence of any noncrystalline impurities in this powder was confirmed by IR spectroscopy, which showed that the spectrum of the single crystals is identical with that observed for the white powder of 1 (Figures S2 and S3). In addition, the magnetic and photomagnetic behaviors of the polycrystalline powder and single-crystal samples are similar because the polycrystalline powder was the subject of a detailed X-ray diffraction study under light. The IR spectrum of 1 shows sharp peaks attributed to the distinctive bond vibration modes of the trz-py molecule. Except the bands attributed to the [Pt­(CN)4]2– anion (Figure S4), the IR spectrum of 1 is similar to that measured for the free trz-py molecule (see the 1600–400 cm–1 region in Figures S2 and S3). Thus, this observation does not allow any direct conclusion on the coordinating character of this organic ligand. However, the blue shift of the characteristic intense C–N stretching band νCN observed at 2167 cm–1, which was located at 2133 and 2122 cm–1 in K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O (Figure S4), reveals the μ4-bridging coordination mode of the [Pt­(CN)4]2– moiety in compound 1. In the low-frequency region, the strong asymmetric doublet, observed at 229 and 225 cm–1, is assigned to the Fe–N stretching vibrations, in agreement with the presence of HS FeII centers at room temperature. The existence of two distinct bands is indicative of the two types of Fe–N bond lengths, as revealed by the crystal structure determination (see below).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Compound 1 was prepared as a polycrystalline powder by adding K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O to an aqueous solution containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole and iron(II) perchlorate in a 1:2:1 ratio. The corresponding single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained using a diffusion technique in fine glass tube (3.0 mm diameter) by careful layering of an aqueous solution containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole and iron(II) perchlorate onto an aqueous solution of K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O. Room-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of the polycrystalline powder was performed to confirm the isomorphism of the powders by comparison with the simulated PXRD pattern for the corresponding single-crystal sample. As is clearly indicated by Figure S1, the measured pattern of a microcrystalline powder of 1 is indeed qualitatively similar to the pattern calculated from the single-crystal crystallographic data. The absence of any noncrystalline impurities in this powder was confirmed by IR spectroscopy, which showed that the spectrum of the single crystals is identical with that observed for the white powder of 1 (Figures S2 and S3). In addition, the magnetic and photomagnetic behaviors of the polycrystalline powder and single-crystal samples are similar because the polycrystalline powder was the subject of a detailed X-ray diffraction study under light. The IR spectrum of 1 shows sharp peaks attributed to the distinctive bond vibration modes of the trz-py molecule. Except the bands attributed to the [Pt(CN)4]2- anion (Figure S4), the IR spectrum of 1 is similar to that measured for the free trz-py molecule (see the 1600-400 cm-1 region in Figures S2 and S3). Thus, this observation does not allow any direct conclusion on the coordinating character of this organic ligand. However, the blue shift of the characteristic intense C-N stretching band νCN observed at 2167 cm-1, which was located at 2133 and 2122 cm-1 in K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O (Figure S4), reveals the μ4-bridging coordination mode of the [Pt(CN)4]2- moiety in compound 1. In the low-frequency region, the strong asymmetric doublet, observed at 229 and 225 cm-1, is assigned to the Fe-N stretching vibrations, in agreement with the presence of HS FeII centers at room temperature. The existence of two distinct bands is indicative of the two types of Fe-N bond lengths, as revealed by the crystal structure determination (see below).

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility (χm) for 1 was determined over the 2–300 K temperature range on a polycrystalline sample. The χm T versus T plot (where T is the temperature) is displayed in a. In the high-temperature region, the χm T value (3.51 cm3·K·mol–1) is consistent with a HS (S = 2) configuration of the hexacoordinated FeII ions.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic and Heat Capacity Studies

The magnetic susceptibility (χm) for 1 was determined over the 2-300 K temperature range on a polycrystalline sample. The χm T versus T plot (where T is the temperature) is displayed in a. In the high-temperature region, the χm T value (3.51 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) is consistent with a HS (S = 2) configuration of the hexacoordinated FeII ions.

elements.content: (a) Thermal dependence of the χm T product for 1 showing the abrupt incomplete spin transition around 153 K. The inset shows an enlarged view of the transition region with the first-order character of the thermal dependence of the χm T product, which is accompanied by a ∼2 K wide hysteresis loop. (b) DSC study for 1 showing the exo- and endothermic transitions. The upper and lower transition temperatures, determined from the maximum of the enthalpic peaks (154.4 and 151.8 K), are in excellent agreement with those of magnetic data. The temperature scan rate was 0.4 K·min–1.

elements.content: Upon cooling, χm T remains almost constant down to ca. 153 K, at which it abruptly decreases to ca. 2.0 cm3·K·mol–1, indicating the presence of an incomplete sharp HS-to-LS SCO first-order phase transition. Below 150 K, the χm T product remains almost constant with a residual fraction of ca. 57% FeII ions in the HS configuration. This χm T value is slightly higher than half of the high-temperature value, 3.51 cm3·K·mol–1 because of the presence of a paramagnetic fraction of ca. 7%, probably arising from a small paramagnetic residue or a dehydrated phase. At very low temperatures, the fraction of HS FeII ions shows the usual zero-field-splitting (ZFS) effect, leading to a decrease of the χm T product. The warming mode shows a slight thermal hysteresis because the spin transition temperatures (T 1/2) for the cooling (T 1/2 down) and warming (T 1/2 up) modes are 152 and 154 K, respectively (see the inset of a), for a temperature scan rate of 0.4 K·min–1. This bistability was clearly confirmed by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) studies in which thermal variation of the heat flow shows exo- and endothermic transitions at 151.8 and 154.4 K, respectively (b). Furthermore, we found that the phase transition occurs with enthalpy and entropy changes of ΔH = 4.8 kJ·mol–1 and ΔS = 30 J·K–1·mol–1, respectively. These values are in good agreement with those reported in the literature for SCO compounds.

elements.content: On the basis of the conclusions derived from thermal variation of the magnetic data and from the calorimetric measurements, the crystal structure of 1 has been determined at 296 and 120 K. The relevant structural modifications induced by light irradiation at 10 K will be detailed in the following sections. Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group. Crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1 and , respectively. The crystal structure of 1 is built from two crystallographically independent FeII sites, Fe1 and Fe2, respectively located on an inversion center (1/4, −1/4, 1/2) and a 2-fold axis (1/2, b, 3/4), one [Pt­(CN)4]2– anion, two monodentate trz-py ligands, and three water solvent molecules located on general positions ().
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

On the basis of the conclusions derived from thermal variation of the magnetic data and from the calorimetric measurements, the crystal structure of 1 has been determined at 296 and 120 K. The relevant structural modifications induced by light irradiation at 10 K will be detailed in the following sections. Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group. Crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1 and , respectively. The crystal structure of 1 is built from two crystallographically independent FeII sites, Fe1 and Fe2, respectively located on an inversion center (1/4, -1/4, 1/2) and a 2-fold axis (1/2, b, 3/4), one [Pt(CN)4]2- anion, two monodentate trz-py ligands, and three water solvent molecules located on general positions ().

The Fe1 and Fe2 iron centers are alternately linked by [Pt­(CN)4]2– anions to form a 2D coordination polymer within corrugated layers corresponding to the a+c and b directions. The 2D network can be described as a succession of Fe4 pseudosquares, in which diagonals are formed by Fe1–Pt1–Fe2 bridges, leading to alternation of Fe1 and Fe2 along the a+c direction (a). Because NC–Pt–CN bridges are a little longer than the pseudosquare diagonals, the [Pt­(CN)4]2– moieties lie slightly out of the plane, leading to corrugation of the 2D layers by a tilt of the FeN4 planes around Fe1 (b). The 2D layers are, furthermore, stacked along the a–c direction; cohesion of the crystal network is assisted in this direction by π–π interactions between the trz-py ligands and a strong hydrogen-bonding network that involves the three water molecules and the noncoordinated N atom of the triazole group of the trz-py ligand (Tables S2 and S3 and and S5).

elements.content: As shown in , the mean Fe2–N distance, ∼2.167(2) Å, is slightly longer than the mean Fe1–N distance, 2.161(2), a difference mainly due to the Fe–N­(trz-py) bonds [Fe1–N5 = 2.178(2) Å and Fe2–N9 = 2.209(2) Å]. A meticulous inspection of the bond distances reveals a more distorted coordination sphere for the Fe2 ion (), which then experiences a significant elastic strain. According to the mean Fe–N distances, both Fe centers are in the HS state at 296 K. Nevertheless, distortion of the octahedral geometries is found to be very small in the HS state for both metal centers, as is usually observed for “Hofmann-like” SCO compounds. The equatorial plane for Fe2 is found to be aligned with that of [Pt­(CN)4]2–, while it deviates significantly by 24.8° for Fe1, leading to corrugation of the 2D network (). At 120 K, the octahedral geometries of the two Fe atoms are significantly different. While the Fe2 environment remains almost unchanged, the Fe1–N bond lengths drastically decrease to reach a mean value of 1.954(2) Å. This feature is the signature of the change of the spin state of Fe1 from HS to LS at low temperature, while Fe2 remains trapped in the HS state, most probably because of the above-mentioned higher distortion of its coordination sphere known to favor the HS state.

elements.content: The angular octahedral geometry of Fe1 is already very regular in the HS state and therefore does not regularize further during the spin transition, as shown by the distortion parameters (see ), which remain almost unchanged between 296 and 120 K. Such a behavior is typical for “Hofmann like” systems. The FeN4 equatorial plane remains in the [Pt­(CN)4]2– plane for Fe2, while the deviation from this plane is still significant for Fe1 (deviation angle = 21.7°) but less pronounced than that observed at room temperature (24.8°; ). These structural features result in an antiferroelastic interaction between the two types of metal centers, which prevents the spin transition of the Fe2 site that remains trapped as HS and therefore explains the magnetic behavior below 150 K. Such elastic interactions are illustrated by Figures S6 and S7, which show deformation of the Fe4 pseudosquares in the low-temperature region. While the Fe4 squares appear very regular at room temperature (a), they progressively distort at 120 K to reach a pseudorectangular geometry (Figure S6). The interlayer distances observed at 120 K are similar to those observed at room temperature but with systematically shorter distances, which is a characteristic of natural thermal contraction (Tables S2 and S3).

elements.content: The photomagnetic properties were first studied on the polycrystalline sample at 10 K. From the intermediate HS–LS state, photoexcitation with green light (510 nm), after 30 min of irradiation, induces an increase of the χm T product from 1.64 to 2.10 cm3·K·mol–1 (). This reveals the occurrence of the LIESST effect and the phototransformation of LS species into HS, thus leading to a sizable population of neighboring molecules in the HS–HS configuration. When the usual T(LIESST) procedure is applied, that is warming in the dark at 0.4 K·min–1, the χm T curves increase up to 3.11 cm3·K·mol–1 at 42 K. This increase is due to ZFS of the two HS FeII ions. Therefore, the maximum reached gives insight into the photoconversion efficiency of ∼90%. Upon further warming in the dark, the χm T product decreases rapidly, due to thermal relaxation, to recover the value of the intermediate state. The derivative of the curve indicates a T(LIESST) value of 52 K.
elements.clean_text:
Photomagnetic Properties

The photomagnetic properties were first studied on the polycrystalline sample at 10 K. From the intermediate HS-LS state, photoexcitation with green light (510 nm), after 30 min of irradiation, induces an increase of the χm T product from 1.64 to 2.10 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (). This reveals the occurrence of the LIESST effect and the phototransformation of LS species into HS, thus leading to a sizable population of neighboring molecules in the HS-HS configuration. When the usual T(LIESST) procedure is applied, that is warming in the dark at 0.4 K⋅min-1, the χm T curves increase up to 3.11 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 42 K. This increase is due to ZFS of the two HS FeII ions. Therefore, the maximum reached gives insight into the photoconversion efficiency of ~90%. Upon further warming in the dark, the χm T product decreases rapidly, due to thermal relaxation, to recover the value of the intermediate state. The derivative of the curve indicates a T(LIESST) value of 52 K.

elements.content: Thermal evolution of the χm T product from high temperature to low temperature in the dark (○) and under 510 nm (△) and 830 nm (▽) light irradiation at 10 K. Green and red ■ are subsequent thermal relaxations in the dark. The temperature sweep rate was 0.4 K·min–1. The power intensity used was 6 mW·cm–2.
elements.clean_text: 6  Thermal evolution of the χm T product from high temperature to low temperature in the dark (○) and under 510 nm (△) and 830 nm (▽) light irradiation at 10 K. Green and red ■ are subsequent thermal relaxations in the dark. The temperature sweep rate was 0.4 K⋅min-1. The power intensity used was 6 mW⋅cm-2.

elements.content: A set of relaxation kinetics were recorded in the dark at several temperatures to derive the physical parameters (activation energy, interaction strength, and frequency factor) governing relaxation of the photoinduced metastable HS fraction (Figure S8). We found that the relaxation curves follow a sigmoidal behavior, in agreement with the cooperative character of the thermal spin transition. To extract the relaxation rate constant at each temperature, we have considered the self-accelerated Hauser’s model, whose physical origin and mean-field character were demonstrated in ref . In this model, the time dependence of the photoconverted HS fraction, γHS, follows the macroscopic master equation d γ HS / d t = − γ HS k HL ( T , γ HS ) where t stands for time and k HL(T,γHS) is the relaxation rate from HS to LS, which depends nonlinearly (due to cooperative effects) on the HS fraction as follows: k HL ( T , γ HS ) = k HL 0 ( T ) ⁡ exp [ ( 1 − γ HS ) E a * / k B T ] where the preexponential factor k HL 0(T) = k ∞ exp­(−E a 0/k B T) is the relaxation rate in the HS state (γHS = 1), E a the corresponding energy barrier, k ∞ is the “spin-flip” frequency from HS to LS at infinite temperature, and E a* is an effective parameter accounting for the interactions between the SCO units, assumed in this simple model as uniform and temperature-independent. We used this model and fitted all experimental relaxation curves of Figure S8, on which we have superimposed the theoretical findings (red lines). The obtained parameter values of the refinement are summarized in Table S4. An excellent agreement is found between the simulation and experimental data. The following values of the thermodynamic parameters E a 0 = 590(18) K, k ∞ = 8.2 s–1, and E a* ∼ 180(18) K were extracted from the Arrhenius plot (ln k HL vs 1/T; inset of Figure S8). To judge the relevance of these data, we compared them to those of the heat capacity measurements. The effective energy barrier E a(γHS) = E a 0 – E a*­(1 – γHS) is exactly equal to the enthalpy of transformation for γHS = 1/2. According to the current photomagnetic data, we derive E a(γHS=1/2) ∼ 500 K per site, which gives an enthalpy change at the transition of ∼4.2 kJ·mol–1 that compares well to the ΔH = 4.8 kJ·mol–1 obtained from the heat capacity measurements. At 10 K, irradiation of the HS–LS state in the near-IR region (830 nm) for 60 min () induces a decrease of the χm T product from 1.64 to 0.82 cm3·K·mol–1, indicating the occurrence of the reverse-LIESST effect and the presence of a sizable population of neighboring molecules in the LS–LS configuration. We could not reach the pure LS state probably because of absorption of light inside the sample. When the T(LIESST) procedure is applied again, the χm T curves, measured in the dark, slightly increase up to a plateau of around 1.1 cm3·K·mol–1 between 30 and 60 K (). This slight increase is attributed to ZFS of the nontransformed fraction of HS Fe2 centers. Upon further warming, the χm T product increases to recover the value of the intermediate state at ∼100 K. The derivative of the curve indicates a T(reverse-LIESST) value of 85 K. The stability of this photoexcited state has been checked through a detailed study of the relaxation kinetics at different temperatures. After irradiation at 10 K at 830 nm, the temperature was increased to 50, 75, 85, and 90 K. After the light was switched off, the temporal evolution of χm T was recorded in isothermal conditions at each fixed temperature, showing a small increase and reaching after 1 h a stationary state whose HS fraction value was lower than that of the HS–LS plateau (Figure S9). Interestingly, and contrary to thermal relaxation of the HS fraction after green-light irradiation, none of the relaxation curves starting from T(reverse-LIESST) reached the plateau. Even those performed at high temperature (∼90 K) saturated after 1 h below the plateau region. Moreover, we observed that T(reverse-LIESST) is weakly influenced by the temperature sweep rate change. Taken together, these results suggest that the LS state induced by the near-IR irradiation most likely corresponds to a stable state. Upon heating, this state undergoes a spin transition at T 1/2 ∼ 85 K, during which presumably only Fe2 sites convert from LS to HS, while Fe1 sites remain trapped in the LS state. Thus, the reverse-LIESST process enabled access to a hidden stable LS state, which was unreachable upon cooling from the high-temperature phase. This particular point will be discussed in the section devoted to the photocrystallographic studies.

elements.content: Let us briefly summarize the key multistability features of the current system at low temperature, according to the data of the LIESST and reverse-LIESST experiments: the stability of the three macroscopic configurations is different. The photoinduced (green light) HS–HS state is metastable and then relaxes back to the intermediate configuration according to a dynamical process described by a self-accelerated model. The HS–LS state (plateau) remains stable or metastable with an extremely long lifetime, as confirmed by the relaxation kinetics from the photoinduced HS–HS state, which stops at the HS–LS plateau and does not cross this limit. Furthermore, relaxation kinetics (time evolution), recorded at 75, 85, and 90 K in the intermediate state for 4 h, did not show any change in the χm T product (Figure S10). This very strong metastability of the intermediate state should be correlated with the above-mentioned distortion of the structure at low temperature, which generates an elastic energy barrier around the Fe2 sites, thus enhancing their metastable character.
elements.clean_text: Let us briefly summarize the key multistability features of the current system at low temperature, according to the data of the LIESST and reverse-LIESST experiments: the stability of the three macroscopic configurations is different. The photoinduced (green light) HS-HS state is metastable and then relaxes back to the intermediate configuration according to a dynamical process described by a self-accelerated model. The HS-LS state (plateau) remains stable or metastable with an extremely long lifetime, as confirmed by the relaxation kinetics from the photoinduced HS-HS state, which stops at the HS-LS plateau and does not cross this limit. Furthermore, relaxation kinetics (time evolution), recorded at 75, 85, and 90 K in the intermediate state for 4 h, did not show any change in the χm T product (Figure S10). This very strong metastability of the intermediate state should be correlated with the above-mentioned distortion of the structure at low temperature, which generates an elastic energy barrier around the Fe2 sites, thus enhancing their metastable character.

elements.content: The existence of the stable LS–LS state paves the way for an interplay and multidirectional photoswitching between these three states. Indeed, at 10 K, the HS–LS intermediate state can be switched to either the HS–HS or LS–LS states, depending on the wavelength used. Moreover, the LS–LS configuration can be directly reached from the HS–HS state by irradiation at 830 nm, and conversely the HS–HS configuration is obtained by irradiation of the LS–LS state at 510 nm (). This bidirectional photoswitching remains effective until 50 K. At 50 K, green-light excitation for 6 h, from either the HS–LS or LS–LS states, leads to the same photostationary state, with the χm T product equal to 2.27 cm3·K·mol–1. This value is very close to the χm T value of the intermediate plateau.
elements.clean_text:
On the Multidirectional Photoswitching

The existence of the stable LS-LS state paves the way for an interplay and multidirectional photoswitching between these three states. Indeed, at 10 K, the HS-LS intermediate state can be switched to either the HS-HS or LS-LS states, depending on the wavelength used. Moreover, the LS-LS configuration can be directly reached from the HS-HS state by irradiation at 830 nm, and conversely the HS-HS configuration is obtained by irradiation of the LS-LS state at 510 nm (). This bidirectional photoswitching remains effective until 50 K. At 50 K, green-light excitation for 6 h, from either the HS-LS or LS-LS states, leads to the same photostationary state, with the χm T product equal to 2.27 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1. This value is very close to the χm T value of the intermediate plateau.

The filled black squares stand for a kinetic recorded in the dark, demonstrating that the decrease observed under 830 nm irradiation is not due to the thermal relaxation effects. The power intensity used was 6 mW·cm–2.

elements.content: Parts a and b of summarize the thermal dependence of the magnetic signal under permanent irradiation in the LIESST and reverse-LIESST regimes, respectively. Here, LITH appears as a result of a dynamical competition between the light excitation, which favors the metastable photoinduced state (the HS–HS state for the green light and the LS–LS state for the red light), and the temperature, which accelerates the sigmoidal relaxation of this photoinduced state, thus stabilizing the HS–LS state for both wavelengths. The competition between these two processes (where the temporal evolution of the HS fraction follows a nonlinear trend) results in a photoinduced thermal instability, which is accompanied by hysteretic behavior. Therefore, the LITH loop reveals the existence of a nonequilibrium transition involving photoinduced and thermally induced states. Because of their dynamical character, usually the LITH loops are very sensitive to the temperature scan rate, leading to wide LITH loops. To access the photostationary (or quasi-static) LITH, given by black curves, we recorded isothermal temporal evolution of the HS fraction under light. The time dependences of the magnetic signals corresponding to these processes are depicted by the vertical lines in a (b), showing that the most significant changes are obtained around 45 and 55 K (50 and 80 K) for the direct (reverse) LITH, i.e., outside the temperature interval quasi-static LITH loop. In contrast, when photoexcitation is performed in the region of the quasi-static LITH curve, the process stops at the quasi-static branch (black curve) of direct- and reverse-LITH loops, whose widths are estimated to be 4 and 25 K, respectively. It is worth noticing that the quasi-static reverse-LITH curve (black curve in b) also matches very well that of the dark (Figure S10). On the other hand, the isothermal temporal evolutions of χm T along the heating branch of the reverse-LITH curve, from the LS–LS state, presented in Figure S11, match perfectly the ones recorded in the dark. The absence of any influence of 830 nm irradiation on the thermal dependence of the LS–LS state upon heating (red and black filled squares of b) and on its relaxation kinetics state, which strengthens the argument that the heating branch of the reverse-LITH curve describes the thermally induced spin transition of a hidden stable LS–LS state toward the LS–HS phase around 80 K.
elements.clean_text:
Light-Induced Thermal Hysteresis (LITH) and Relative Stability of the Intermediate State

Parts a and b of  summarize the thermal dependence of the magnetic signal under permanent irradiation in the LIESST and reverse-LIESST regimes, respectively. Here, LITH appears as a result of a dynamical competition between the light excitation, which favors the metastable photoinduced state (the HS-HS state for the green light and the LS-LS state for the red light), and the temperature, which accelerates the sigmoidal relaxation of this photoinduced state, thus stabilizing the HS-LS state for both wavelengths. The competition between these two processes (where the temporal evolution of the HS fraction follows a nonlinear trend) results in a photoinduced thermal instability, which is accompanied by hysteretic behavior. Therefore, the LITH loop reveals the existence of a nonequilibrium transition involving photoinduced and thermally induced states. Because of their dynamical character, usually the LITH loops are very sensitive to the temperature scan rate, leading to wide LITH loops. To access the photostationary (or quasi-static) LITH, given by black curves, we recorded isothermal temporal evolution of the HS fraction under light. The time dependences of the magnetic signals corresponding to these processes are depicted by the vertical lines in a (b), showing that the most significant changes are obtained around 45 and 55 K (50 and 80 K) for the direct (reverse) LITH, i.e., outside the temperature interval quasi-static LITH loop. In contrast, when photoexcitation is performed in the region of the quasi-static LITH curve, the process stops at the quasi-static branch (black curve) of direct- and reverse-LITH loops, whose widths are estimated to be 4 and 25 K, respectively. It is worth noticing that the quasi-static reverse-LITH curve (black curve in b) also matches very well that of the dark (Figure S10). On the other hand, the isothermal temporal evolutions of χm T along the heating branch of the reverse-LITH curve, from the LS-LS state, presented in Figure S11, match perfectly the ones recorded in the dark. The absence of any influence of 830 nm irradiation on the thermal dependence of the LS-LS state upon heating (red and black filled squares of b) and on its relaxation kinetics state, which strengthens the argument that the heating branch of the reverse-LITH curve describes the thermally induced spin transition of a hidden stable LS-LS state toward the LS-HS phase around 80 K.

Temporal evolution of the photoconverted HS fraction in isothermal conditions (T = 45, 50, and 55 K) [75, 85, and 90 K] toward photostationary states: upon heating from the HS–LS state (green △) [LS–LS state (red △)] and upon cooling from the HS–HS state (green ▽) [HS-LS state (red ▽)] at 60, 55, and 50 K. The black curves stand for the quasi-static hysteresis loops, which are indicative of the real static loops. The temperature scan rate was 0.4 K·min–1 for both experiments, and the power intensity was 6 mW·cm–2.

elements.content: Upon cooling from the plateau region, near-IR irradiation favored the occurrence of the reversible HS–LS → LS–LS transition around 50 K. In this way, a closed thermal hysteresis loop related to the transition of the Fe2 center was observed, while in the dark the system remained desperately trapped in the intermediate state. This behavior indicates the presence of a hidden thermal hysteresis in the HS–LS plateau, which was not accessible in the thermally induced process.
elements.clean_text: Upon cooling from the plateau region, near-IR irradiation favored the occurrence of the reversible HS-LS → LS-LS transition around 50 K. In this way, a closed thermal hysteresis loop related to the transition of the Fe2 center was observed, while in the dark the system remained desperately trapped in the intermediate state. This behavior indicates the presence of a hidden thermal hysteresis in the HS-LS plateau, which was not accessible in the thermally induced process.

elements.content: To study the dynamical properties of the corresponding cooling branch of the reverse LITH loop, we carried out partial excitations using near-IR light at 10 K, followed by thermal relaxation of the magnetic response in the dark. The obtained results are summarized in . All partial reverse-LIESST photoexcitations (blue, red, and olive curves) of the Fe2 centers from HS to LS show, upon heating, typical trends of thermal relaxation of a part of the photoconverted Fe2 HS fraction toward the LS state, with a relaxation temperature (located at the inflection points of the curves, dashed line) that decreases as photoexcitation progresses. Besides, the location of the relaxation temperatures, represented by the dashed black curve in , matches quite well with that of the photostationary states, depicted in b (full black line).
elements.clean_text:
Partial Photoexcitation

To study the dynamical properties of the corresponding cooling branch of the reverse LITH loop, we carried out partial excitations using near-IR light at 10 K, followed by thermal relaxation of the magnetic response in the dark. The obtained results are summarized in . All partial reverse-LIESST photoexcitations (blue, red, and olive curves) of the Fe2 centers from HS to LS show, upon heating, typical trends of thermal relaxation of a part of the photoconverted Fe2 HS fraction toward the LS state, with a relaxation temperature (located at the inflection points of the curves, dashed line) that decreases as photoexcitation progresses. Besides, the location of the relaxation temperatures, represented by the dashed black curve in , matches quite well with that of the photostationary states, depicted in b (full black line).

elements.content: Thermal evolution of the magnetic response in the dark, subsequent to partial photoexcitations using 830 nm wavelength for 4 min (blue), 6 min (red), 8 min (green), and 60 min (black) light irradiation. All curves first show an increase of the magnetic signal due to ZFS effects, followed by thermal relaxation of the photoconverted HS fraction toward the “LS” state, before joining the upper heating branch at which the system reaches the limit of metastability. elements.content: In light of these photomagnetic studies, the crystal structure has been further derived at 10 K in the three relevant configurations from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, i.e., in the HS–LS state upon cooling from 120 K, after irradiation with a 532 nm solid state laser, and after irradiation with a 808 nm diode laser. These three states are called IP2, HS2, and LS hereafter. The structural topology described above was retained at 10 K in all three states, and no space group change occurred. Upon a temperature decrease from 120 K (IP1) to 10 K (IP2), only marginal modifications attributed to thermal contraction effects occurred; the mean Fe1–N and Fe2–N bond distances only slightly decreased within standard deviations. Upon irradiation with 808 nm from the IP2 phase, the Fe2–N bond distances drastically decreased to a mean value of 1.964(3) Å, which is characteristic of a complete HS-to-LS spin-state change for this Fe2 site, while Fe1 remained in the LS state, in agreement with the photomagnetic data. In contrast, irradiation with 532 nm from the IP2 phase led to a large increase in the Fe1–N bond distances, indicative of a LS-to-HS spin-state change for Fe1. Altogether, the crystallographic results () confirm the multidirectional photoswitching features, observed in photomagnetic studies, between the three states LS–LS, LS–HS, and HS–HS at 10 K. Although not shown here, reversible direct photoswitching between photoexcited HS–HS and LS–LS states was also possible in photocrystallography. In all three states, the difference in angular distortion between Fe1 and Fe2, which is a higher distortion for Fe2, was preserved, especially in the HS2 state, while Fe1 and Fe2 are both assigned a HS state. Corrugation of the 2D layer, as evidenced by the tilt of the Fe1N4 plane with respect to the Fe2N4 plane, increased continuously from the LS [19.3(2)°] to IP2 [22.4(2)°] to HS2 [28.6(2)°] states (). As shown by the square distortion parameter Sd (see for its definition), deformation of the pseudosquares around the Fe atoms within the 2D layers is always higher around Fe2 and much reduced in the LS and HS states compared to the IP state, which exhibits therefore the most important elastic strain ( and a and S6, S7, S12, and S13). The latter is most likely at the origin of stabilization of the ordered antiferroelastic HS–LS structure of the plateau region. The corresponding Fe···Fe and Pt···Pt distances ( and Figures S7, S12, and S13) range from 7.064(1) to 7.662(1) Å in the IP2 state. It is interesting to note that in each case the difference within the Fe···Fe distances is much smaller than that within the Pt···Pt distances, which then absorb a part of the structure change resulting from the HS-to-LS conversion of Fe1. This is obvious for the IP2 case, where the Pt···Pt distances range from 7.064(1) to 7.662(1) Å, while the Fe···Fe distances range only from 7.248(1) to 7.308(1) Å. An additional inspection of the temperature changes of the Fe···Fe and Pt···Pt distances shows that, from the outset at ambient temperature, the three Pt–Fe–Pt–Fe pseudosquares show that the largest Pt–Pt distance is systematically obtained for the Fe2–Pt–Fe2–Pt pseudosquare. This introduces an elastic frustration, maintaining the Fe2 site in the HS state. When the temperature is decreased from 296 K and contrary to the other two, the largest Pt···Pt distance first increases at 120 K, before collapsing at lower temperatures. When the Fe–N distances between the three states are more closely examined, this elastic distortion becomes obvious. The average Fe–N distances do not change significantly if the corresponding spin state does not change. That is to say, ⟨Fe1–N⟩ is identical for LS and IP2, while ⟨Fe2–N⟩ is identical for HS and IP2. On the contrary, individual Fe–N distances exhibit significant changes of about 2–3 standard deviations. This originates from the local distortion of the Fe1 (Fe2) octahedron as a response to the spin-state change of Fe2 (Fe1) from IP2 to LS (HS2).

The latter is most likely at the origin of stabilization of the ordered antiferroelastic HS-LS structure of the plateau region. The corresponding Fe⋅⋅⋅Fe and Pt⋅⋅⋅Pt distances ( and Figures S7, S12, and S13) range from 7.064(1) to 7.662(1) Å in the IP2 state. This introduces an elastic frustration, maintaining the Fe2 site in the HS state. When the temperature is decreased from 296 K and contrary to the other two, the largest Pt⋅⋅⋅Pt distance first increases at 120 K, before collapsing at lower temperatures. When the Fe-N distances between the three states are more closely examined, this elastic distortion becomes obvious. The average Fe-N distances do not change significantly if the corresponding spin state does not change. That is to say, ⟨Fe1-N⟩ is identical for LS and IP2, while ⟨Fe2-N⟩ is identical for HS and IP2. On the contrary, individual Fe-N distances exhibit significant changes of about 2-3 standard deviations. elements.content: A new Hofmann-type framework SCO system (1) has been prepared. Its structure consists of [FePt­(CN)4] layers separated by interdigited trz-py ligands with two inequivalent FeII sites. The 2D network can be described as a succession of Fe4 pseudosquares, the diagonals of which are formed by Fe1–Pt–Fe2 bridges. Interlayer contacts are assisted by π–π interactions between the trz-py ligands and a strong hydrogen-bonding network that involves three noncoordinated water molecules. 1 exhibits an incomplete sharp SCO first-order phase transition centered at 153 K from a HS–HS to a HS–LS structurally ordered state. Irradiation at 10 K with green light induces a photoswitching to the HS–HS state, characterized by a T(LIESST) value of 52 K. Photomagnetic measurements show that the HS–HS state is metastable and relaxes back to the intermediate HS–LS plateau with self-accelerated relaxations, typical for a highly cooperative SCO system. On the contrary, irradiation of the HS–LS state with near-IR light is efficient only below the T(LIESST) value of the direct LIESST process and leads to the emergence of a hidden stable LS–LS state with a markedly different T(reverse-LIESST) value of 85 K. Contrary to the relaxation behavior of the HS–HS state, relaxations from the LS–LS state do not reach the HS–LS plateau, which shows that the LS–LS state is a stable one and, correlatively, the HS–LS state is metastable. The LITH curve associated with the reverse-LIESST process consists of a wide thermal hysteresis whose quasi-static hysteresis loop ranges between 55 and 85 K. Altogether, these results prove the presence of a hidden hysteresis in the HS–LS plateau, which was not accessible due to the slowing down of the relaxation processes upon cooling, with the Fe2 site being trapped in the HS state. Irradiation with near-IR light induces its switching to the LS state. The photocrystallographic investigations for the three 10 K states indicate that the structural topology is retained and no space group change occurs along the bidirectional switching. The very strong metastability of the intermediate HS–LS state originates from antiferroelastic interactions (frustration) within the [FePt­(CN)4] layers, accommodated by NC–Pt–CN bridges between inequivalent SCO active FeII sites. This elastic distortion manifests itself in corrugation of the 2D layers and deformation of the square Fe–Pt–Fe–Pt structural topology. The HS–LS state exhibits the most important elastic distortion, which explains its strong metastability, at the origin of its long lifetime. Most interestingly, these results, and especially the existence of the stable LS–LS state, pave the way for an interplay and multidirectional photoswitching between these three states.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A new Hofmann-type framework SCO system (1) has been prepared. Its structure consists of [FePt(CN)4] layers separated by interdigited trz-py ligands with two inequivalent FeII sites. The 2D network can be described as a succession of Fe4 pseudosquares, the diagonals of which are formed by Fe1-Pt-Fe2 bridges. Interlayer contacts are assisted by π-π interactions between the trz-py ligands and a strong hydrogen-bonding network that involves three noncoordinated water molecules. 1 exhibits an incomplete sharp SCO first-order phase transition centered at 153 K from a HS-HS to a HS-LS structurally ordered state. Irradiation at 10 K with green light induces a photoswitching to the HS-HS state, characterized by a T(LIESST) value of 52 K. Photomagnetic measurements show that the HS-HS state is metastable and relaxes back to the intermediate HS-LS plateau with self-accelerated relaxations, typical for a highly cooperative SCO system. On the contrary, irradiation of the HS-LS state with near-IR light is efficient only below the T(LIESST) value of the direct LIESST process and leads to the emergence of a hidden stable LS-LS state with a markedly different T(reverse-LIESST) value of 85 K. Contrary to the relaxation behavior of the HS-HS state, relaxations from the LS-LS state do not reach the HS-LS plateau, which shows that the LS-LS state is a stable one and, correlatively, the HS-LS state is metastable. The LITH curve associated with the reverse-LIESST process consists of a wide thermal hysteresis whose quasi-static hysteresis loop ranges between 55 and 85 K. Altogether, these results prove the presence of a hidden hysteresis in the HS-LS plateau, which was not accessible due to the slowing down of the relaxation processes upon cooling, with the Fe2 site being trapped in the HS state. Irradiation with near-IR light induces its switching to the LS state. The photocrystallographic investigations for the three 10 K states indicate that the structural topology is retained and no space group change occurs along the bidirectional switching. The very strong metastability of the intermediate HS-LS state originates from antiferroelastic interactions (frustration) within the [FePt(CN)4] layers, accommodated by NC-Pt-CN bridges between inequivalent SCO active FeII sites. This elastic distortion manifests itself in corrugation of the 2D layers and deformation of the square Fe-Pt-Fe-Pt structural topology. The HS-LS state exhibits the most important elastic distortion, which explains its strong metastability, at the origin of its long lifetime. Most interestingly, these results, and especially the existence of the stable LS-LS state, pave the way for an interplay and multidirectional photoswitching between these three states.

elements.content: 2-Aminopyridine, diformylhydrazine, potassium tetracyanoplatinate, and iron­(II) perchlorate were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Solvents were used and purified by standard procedures. Elemental analyses were performed by the Service Central d’Analyses du CNRS, Gif-sur-Yvette, France. IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000–50 cm–1 on a Bruker ATR Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Remarks

2-Aminopyridine, diformylhydrazine, potassium tetracyanoplatinate, and iron(II) perchlorate were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Solvents were used and purified by standard procedures. Elemental analyses were performed by the Service Central d'Analyses du CNRS, Gif-sur-Yvette, France. IR spectra were recorded in the range 4000-50 cm-1 on a Bruker ATR Vertex 70 FT-IR spectrometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray studies were performed at 296 and 120 K using a Bruker APEX2 κ-CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Single-crystal diffraction data (10 K) were collected on a Microfocus Supernova diffractometer equipped with a 2D ATLAS detector, using Mo Kα radiation, and a Helijet helium open-flow cryosystem. Numerical absorption correction was performed. In situ photoexcitations were carried out using a 808 nm diode laser (duration 15 min) and a 532 nm solid-state laser (duration 20 min) until the photostationary state was reached in each case to populate the LS and HS2 states, respectively. The single-crystal sample was rotated continuously during excitation to ensure a homogeneous and complete excitation. The corresponding structures were solved by direct methods with the SHELXS program and refined on F 2 by weighted full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXL program. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, and H atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and treated using a riding model. Crystallographic data and refinement details are provided in Table S1. The room-temperature PXRD spectrum was recorded on a PANalytical Empyrean powder X-ray diffractometer at 45 kV and 40 mA with a copper-target tube (Figure S1). NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX 300 MHz. DSC measurements were performed on a Mettler-Toledo DSC-1/LN2 calorimeter, with the heat flow scan rate set at s = 0.3 K·min–1. Magnetic and photomagnetic measurements were performed with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer in the 2–300 K temperature range with an applied magnetic field of 2 T upon the assembly of single crystals of compound 1 (with a mass of 0.68 mg). Photomagnetic characterizations of compound 1 were carried out using a set of photodiodes. Irradiation was carried out at 10 K several times using different wavelengths (i.e., 405, 510, 650, 830, and 980 nm) to determine the most efficient conditions to reach a strong photoconversion yield at photosaturation. Power intensities of 6 mW·cm–2 at 510 nm and 10 mW·cm–2 at 830 nm were used. LIESST experiments were performed using a 510 nm wavelength. After irradiation was switched off, the temperature was increased at a rate of 0.4 K·min–1 up to 100 K, to determine the T(LIESST) value, and from 100 K to 300 K to 10 K, to follow the thermal spin transition. The T(LIESST) value was determined as the minimum of the ∂χm T/∂T versus T plot (maximum slope in the χm T vs T plot), corresponding to the temperature at which the light-induced HS information is erased. For the kinetic study, the sample was irradiated at 10 K until saturation of the HS fraction, and then the temperature was set to 10, 20, 25, 30, 35, and 40 K and the light was switched off in order to study the relaxation kinetics at these temperatures. Reverse-LIESST experiments were performed by irradiating the sample at 10 K in the plateau region with a 830 nm diode laser (5 mW·cm–2), until saturation of the LS state was reached. All of the experiments performed under or after light irradiation were done using a 0.4 K·min–1 temperature scanning rate.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (10 mL) containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (146 mg, 1.0 mmol) and iron­(II) perchlorate (127.5 mg, 0.5 mmol) was left standing overnight. To the resulting light-yellow solution was added K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O (188.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature. The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and dried (yield 79%, 278 mg). Anal. Calcd for C18H18FeN12O3Pt: C, 30.8; H, 2.6; N, 24.0. Found: C, 31.1; H, 2.6; N, 24.4 (see Figure S2 for IR data). Single crystals of 1 were prepared by slow diffusion in a fine glass tube (3.0 mm diameter) of two aqueous solutions: the first solution was obtained by dissolving K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O (37.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 10 mL. The second solution was prepared by dissolving Fe­(ClO4)2·xH2O (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a solution (10 mL) of 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (29.2 mg, 0.2 mmol). After standing overnight, a light-yellow coloration appeared. A total of 2 mL of the K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O solution was placed in the fine glass tube, and a similar volume of the yellow solution was added carefully in order to limit mixing of the two solutions. After 2 days, colorless small fine square crystals of 1 had formed by slow diffusion. The IR spectrum of such single crystals is identical with that observed for the white powder of 1 (Figure S3).

Upon heating above room temperature (380 K), 1 loses its solvent water molecules to reach a dehydrated state, for which a magnetic study shows paramagnetic behavior in agreement with the absence of any SCO transition in the 2–380 K temperature range. This dehydrated phase could also be partially obtained by the vacuum made in the SQUID magnetometer, as is clearly evidenced by a ca. 7% excess of the expected (50%) residual fraction of HS FeII ions below 150 K.

The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and dried (yield 79%, 278 mg). Anal. Calcd for C18H18FeN12O3Pt: C, 30.8; H, 2.6; N, 24.0. Found: C, 31.1; H, 2.6; N, 24.4 (see Figure S2 for IR data). Single crystals of 1 were prepared by slow diffusion in a fine glass tube (3.0 mm diameter) of two aqueous solutions: the first solution was obtained by dissolving K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O (37.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 10 mL. The second solution was prepared by dissolving Fe­(ClO4)2·xH2O (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a solution (10 mL) of 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (29.2 mg, 0.2 mmol). After standing overnight, a light-yellow coloration appeared. A total of 2 mL of the K2[Pt­(CN)4]·xH2O solution was placed in the fine glass tube, and a similar volume of the yellow solution was added carefully in order to limit mixing of the two solutions. After 2 days, colorless small fine square crystals of 1 had formed by slow diffusion. The IR spectrum of such single crystals is identical with that observed for the white powder of 1 (Figure S3).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Fe(trz-py)2{Pt(CN)4}]⋅3H2O (1)

An aqueous solution (10 mL) containing 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (146 mg, 1.0 mmol) and iron(II) perchlorate (127.5 mg, 0.5 mmol) was left standing overnight. To the resulting light-yellow solution was added K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O (188.5 mg, 0.5 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature. The resulting white precipitate was filtered off and dried (yield 79%, 278 mg). Anal. Calcd for C18H18FeN12O3Pt: C, 30.8; H, 2.6; N, 24.0. Found: C, 31.1; H, 2.6; N, 24.4 (see Figure S2 for IR data). Single crystals of 1 were prepared by slow diffusion in a fine glass tube (3.0 mm diameter) of two aqueous solutions: the first solution was obtained by dissolving K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O (37.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 10 mL. The second solution was prepared by dissolving Fe(ClO4)2⋅xH2O (25.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in a solution (10 mL) of 4-(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,4H-triazole (29.2 mg, 0.2 mmol). After standing overnight, a light-yellow coloration appeared. A total of 2 mL of the K2[Pt(CN)4]⋅xH2O solution was placed in the fine glass tube, and a similar volume of the yellow solution was added carefully in order to limit mixing of the two solutions. After 2 days, colorless small fine square crystals of 1 had formed by slow diffusion. The IR spectrum of such single crystals is identical with that observed for the white powder of 1 (Figure S3).

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic susceptibility (χm) for 1 was determined over the 2–300 K temperature range on a polycrystalline sample. The χm T versus T plot (where T is the temperature) is displayed in a. In the high-temperature region, the χm T value (3.51 cm3·K·mol–1) is consistent with a HS (S = 2) configuration of the hexacoordinated FeII ions.

Photomagnetic Properties

The photomagnetic properties were first studied on the polycrystalline sample at 10 K. From the intermediate HS–LS state, photoexcitation with green light (510 nm), after 30 min of irradiation, induces an increase of the χm T product from 1.64 to 2.10 cm3·K·mol–1 (). This reveals the occurrence of the LIESST effect and the phototransformation of LS species into HS, thus leading to a sizable population of neighboring molecules in the HS–HS configuration. When the usual T(LIESST) procedure is applied, that is warming in the dark at 0.4 K·min–1, the χm T curves increase up to 3.11 cm3·K·mol–1 at 42 K. This increase is due to ZFS of the two HS FeII ions. Therefore, the maximum reached gives insight into the photoconversion efficiency of ∼90%. Upon further warming in the dark, the χm T product decreases rapidly, due to thermal relaxation, to recover the value of the intermediate state. The derivative of the curve indicates a T(LIESST) value of 52 K.

Magnetic and Heat Capacity Studies

In the high-temperature region, the χm T value (3.51 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1) is consistent with a HS (S = 2) configuration of the hexacoordinated FeII ions.

Photomagnetic Properties

The photomagnetic properties were first studied on the polycrystalline sample at 10 K. From the intermediate HS-LS state, photoexcitation with green light (510 nm), after 30 min of irradiation, induces an increase of the χm T product from 1.64 to 2.10 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (). When the usual T(LIESST) procedure is applied, that is warming in the dark at 0.4 K⋅min-1, the χm T curves increase up to 3.11 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 42 K. This increase is due to ZFS of the two HS FeII ions. Therefore, the maximum reached gives insight into the photoconversion efficiency of ~90%. Upon further warming in the dark, the χm T product decreases rapidly, due to thermal relaxation, to recover the value of the intermediate state. The derivative of the curve indicates a T(LIESST) value of 52 K.

cln_elements.content: (a) Thermal dependence of the χm T product for 1 showing the abrupt incomplete spin transition around 153 K. The inset shows an enlarged view of the transition region with the first-order character of the thermal dependence of the χm T product, which is accompanied by a ∼2 K wide hysteresis loop. (b) DSC study for 1 showing the exo- and endothermic transitions. The upper and lower transition temperatures, determined from the maximum of the enthalpic peaks (154.4 and 151.8 K), are in excellent agreement with those of magnetic data. The temperature scan rate was 0.4 K·min–1.

cln_elements.content: Thermal evolution of the magnetic response in the dark, subsequent to partial photoexcitations using 830 nm wavelength for 4 min (blue), 6 min (red), 8 min (green), and 60 min (black) light irradiation. All curves first show an increase of the magnetic signal due to ZFS effects, followed by thermal relaxation of the photoconverted HS fraction toward the “LS” state, before joining the upper heating branch at which the system reaches the limit of metastability. The temperature sweep rate was 0.4 K·min–1. The dashed black curve represents the locus of relaxation temperatures (inflection points). The black continuous curve stands for the quasi-static hysteresis loop obtained in Figure b (power intensity = 6 mW·cm–2).
